1f:T9ac,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Milanesa a la Napolitana","description":"Argentina's answer to chicken parm — a breaded cutlet topped with tomato sauce, ham, and melted mozzarella. Despite the name, it has nothing to do with Naples. Pure Argentine comfort food.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/milanesa-napolitana.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT20M","cookTime":"PT25M","totalTime":"PT45M","recipeYield":"4 servings","recipeCategory":"main","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"milanesa napolitana recipe, argentine breaded cutlet, milanesa a la napolitana, milanesa con queso, argentine comfort food","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"580 calories","proteinContent":"38g","carbohydrateContent":"35g","fatContent":"32g"},"recipeIngredient":["Milanesas: 4 thin beef or chicken cutlets (about 200g each), pounded thin","Milanesas: 2 eggs, beaten","Milanesas: 2 cups breadcrumbs","Milanesas: Salt, pepper, garlic powder to taste","Milanesas: Oil for frying","Napolitana topping: 1 cup tomato sauce (salsa de tomate)","Napolitana topping: 4 slices cooked ham (jamón cocido)","Napolitana topping: 200g mozzarella cheese, sliced","Napolitana topping: 1 tsp dried oregano","Napolitana topping: Olives and roasted peppers for garnish (optional)"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Season the cutlets with salt, pepper, and garlic powder."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"Dip each cutlet in beaten egg, then press firmly into breadcrumbs on both sides."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat (about 1cm deep)."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Fry each milanesa for 2-3 minutes per side until golden and crispy. Drain on paper towels."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Place fried milanesas on a baking sheet."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"Spoon tomato sauce over each milanesa."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Top with a slice of ham, then mozzarella slices."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"Sprinkle with oregano."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Broil in the oven at 200°C (400°F) for 5-7 minutes until cheese is melted and bubbly."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":10,"text":"Serve immediately with french fries (papas fritas) — the mandatory accompaniment."}]}17:["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$1f"}}],["$","div",null,{"className":"border-b bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-sm sticky top-0 z-40 print:hidden","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-5xl mx-auto px-4 py-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-center justify-between","children":["$","$L6",null,{"href":"/food/recipes","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 h-4","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1l729n",{"d":"m12 19-7-7 7-7"}],["$","path","x3x0zl",{"d":"M19 12H5"}],"$undefined"]}],"All gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Pound the cutlets thin and even — they should be about 5mm thick."}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Double-dip for extra crunch: egg → breadcrumbs → egg → breadcrumbs."}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Fry first, THEN add toppings and bake. Never skip the frying step."}]]}],["$","li","3",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The tomato sauce should be simple — not chunky marinara. Argentine salsa de tomate is smooth."}]]}],["$","li","4",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"French fries are non-negotiable. A napolitana without papas fritas is incomplete."}]]}],["$","li","5",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Some restaurants offer 'a caballo' — topped with a fried egg. Highly recommended."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
2e:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Despite the Italian-sounding name, milanesa a la napolitana was invented in Buenos Aires in the 1940s by chef José Napoli at the restaurant Nápoli on Avenida Corrientes. He topped a breaded cutlet with ham, cheese, and tomato sauce — and a porteño classic was born. The name honors the restaurant, not the Italian city. It remains one of the most ordered dishes in Argentine restaurants today."}]}]]}]
2f:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Best eaten fresh. Leftover breaded cutlets (without topping) can be frozen for up to 2 months. Reheat in a 200°C oven."}]}]]}]
1c:[["$","meta","0",{"charSet":"utf-8"}],["$","meta","1",{"name":"viewport","content":"width=device-width, initial-scale=1"}]]
30:I[17124,["/_next/static/chunks/f7a6a5c10098787e.js","/_next/static/chunks/0228e4c449c3a8b8.js"],"IconMark"]
1a:null
